Liabilities

Liabilities are legal obligations that will require the company to transfer ownership of assets to an outside individual or organization at some point in the future.

Examples of liabilities include:

  • Wages Payable
  • Notes Payable
  • Taxes Payable
  • Interest Payable
  • Unearned Revenue
  • Long Term Lease Payable
  • Bonds Payable

A company's liabilities are represented by permanent accounts listed on the balance sheet. Liability accounts carry a credit balance. According to the accounting equation, all of a company's liabilities are equal to assets minus equity.

Liabilities can be broken down into current and non-current liabilities.

Current liabilities are those that are expected to be settled during the current reporting cycle or year. Examples of current liabilities include wages payable, taxes payable, and unearned revenue which will require the company to give up goods or render services during the current reporting cycle or year. The principle on a mortgage that is coming due is represented with a current liability account.

Non-current liabilities are liabilities that will not require servicing during the current reporting cycle or year. Examples of non-current liabilities include bonds payable, notes payable, and mortgage payable.

Generally speaking, liabilities provide companies with cash, materials and services needed to operate. Unlike equity, liabilities provide these resources without sacrificing ownership. Suppose a company purchases a fleet of cars from a dealership and agrees to pay over several years through a lease agreement. Under normal circumstances the car dealership cannot influence any decision making over the company, nor can they claim additional assets relative to the the success of the company. The trade-off is that the liability does not go away if the company fails. Creditors get first dibs on a company's assets should the company go out of business and can legally force the liquidation of assets in order to settle debts.
